timeline.bodyText:
I'm not sure about this one. It seems like a semantic difference unless I'm reading it wrong?
It used to be:
CASE1 - if (cid != 0 && cid != -1) -> a review was undone
CASE2 - else if (cid != -1) -> reset and get new card
That combination means "reset and get new card" will happen for all cid where cid is anything but 0 or -1
Now it is
CASE1 if (cid == 0) -> reset and get new card
CASE2 if (cid != 1) -> a review was undone
Now it is only doing a reset and get new card if cid == 0. That's a much smaller set of cid's that will reset and get new card. Is that valid?
Am I missing something?
timeline.author: mikehardy

replies.bodyText:
In the new case 2, you probably meant "cid != -1". instead of "cid != 1". You forgot a minus sign.
Essentially, if you used to go to case 2, it means that cid == 0, since you know that it is not different from both 0 and -1.
Mathematically, the proof is long but easy.
, "reset and get a new card" only occurred iff
"(not (cid != 0 && cid != -1)) and (cid !=-1)" the first of the conjunction because it's in the "else" part.
iff
"(not cid !=0 || not cid !=-1) and (cid!= -1)"
iff
"(cid ==0 || cid ==-1) && (cid !=-1)"
iff
"(cid ==0 && cid !=-1) || (cid ==-1&&cid!=-1)"
iff
"(cid ==0)|| false"
iff
"cid ==0", which means that it currently execute "reset and get new card"
Now "a review was undone" occurs iff
"(not (cid ==0)) && cid !=-1)"
iff
"cid !=0 && cid !=-1"
iff "a review was undone" in the previous case
So both codes are equivalent, but the second one is quite more clear I believe
